captions.text:
So, here&#39;s an insider glimpse of how the sausage 
is made: a bunch of pigs undergo extremely

traumatic violence and then get their todgers 
minced up and arranged into the shape of a larger

todger as a sort of final insult. Now, here&#39;s a 
glimpse of how the METAPHORICAL sausage is made:

I was gonna review a different game this week. But 
after I finished that, I had some time to kill,

and the gimp was out dropping his daughter off at 
clarinet practice, so I thought, &quot;Fuck it, I&#39;ll

just idly play a bit more of that silly game I 
played in this week&#39;s Yahtzee Tries; I was rather

enjoying it.&quot; Four days later, I now find I would 
much rather talk about it than the other game I

had lined up, which, naming no names and meaning 
no shade, was a sequel whose title began with the

words &quot;Revenge of,&quot; and perhaps that will help 
you understand my relative lack of enthusiasm.

I&#39;m always much more interested in reviewing games 
I really like or acquire a passionate hate boner

for, and in the interest of suspense, I won&#39;t give 
away just yet which was the case. Although I will

incidentally admit that &quot;passionate hate boner&quot; 
is the name of my new line of artisanal sausages.

Promise Mascot Agency is a game by the guys 
who did Paradise Killer, a UK-based developer,

and yet, PMA feels authentically like a Japanese 
game. It&#39;s like the combined powers of all the

world&#39;s weirdly influential small island nations 
full of extremely repressed people. The story is,

we play a Yakuza enforcer with distinct Kazuma 
Kiryu energy—partly thanks to also having distinct

Kazuma Kiryu voice acting, incidentally—who loses 
his boss&#39;s money in a bungled deal and is cut off

from the family while he lies low and tries to 
make up for his mistake. Also known as &quot;pulling a

Tommy Vercetti.&quot; What I haven&#39;t yet mentioned is 
that this all takes place in contemporary Japan

in a world identical to our own except that 
humanity lives alongside a race of freakish

sentient mascot characters who struggle to get 
footholds in any industry other than prancing

around at theme parks and store openings, and 
our protagonist must take charge of a failing

mascot agency in a dying rural Japanese town to 
help the local disgusting mutants realize their

full potential for prancing around at theme 
parks and store openings. So setting-wise,

it&#39;s like Japanese District 9 except with 
a race of big-headed Hello Kitty people.

My enjoyment of Promise Mascot Agency—whoops, gave 
the game away there; yes, it&#39;s a positive review,

put away those artisanal hate boners or whatever 
I was on about—might simply be down to that it

makes me laugh. Here&#39;s the two leads. On the left, 
macho, takes-no-shit Yakuza man with very serious

face, and on the right, his assistant, a giant 
pink blob with huge eyes and cute sideways three

mouth who&#39;s supposed to resemble the severed end 
of a pinky finger. And who provides the reckless,

psychotic id to the calm, unflappable superego of 
the protagonist as he lets the insanity wash over

him like a stone Buddha in the middle of a crowded 
McDonald&#39;s play area. I love the juxtaposition of

deadpan and wacky as a comedic foundation. It&#39;s 
why I like Yakuza games. And there&#39;s a lot of

Yakuza in Promise Mascot Agency&#39;s gameplay. 
The core of it is like one of those Yakuza

side quests where you get roped into running a 
hostess club or artisanal sausage factory and

play little business sim minigames where you 
assign specific hostesses to specific tables

or scare health inspectors away from the todger 
storage vats. So, we assign our recruited mascots

to the jobs we&#39;ve secured via a basic menu system, 
and while we wait to hear back, we drive a truck

around a sandbox map, hunting for more work, 
more mascots, secret pickups, and firing our

giant severed pinky finger assistant out of 
a cannon at anything that looks at us funny.

And while out driving, we&#39;re randomly called 
in to deal with emergencies at the mascot jobs,

which we resolve by playing a card battling game. 
&quot;Business management, sandbox driving around,

and card battling? Blimey, Yahtz. Who designed 
this game, Jackson Pollock?&quot; I know it sounds

all over the place, but the loops tie up quite 
nicely. We explore the sandbox to find items

to help the townsfolk to empower their battle 
cards to win the card battles to earn money to

send back to our Yakuza boss so she doesn&#39;t get 
murdered by frighteners. It all spirals together

into that one central point. Now, the weak link in 
this chain is probably the card battling itself.

It looks complicated, but turns out, all you have 
to do is play the cards with the biggest numbers;

it&#39;s basically massively overly elaborate Top 
Trumps with about two minutes of mashing A through

the 15 dialogues and screen transitions 
you&#39;ve already memorized after the first

90 fucking times. It does get more interesting 
later when you have to hit the bigger numbers,

requiring enough upgraded cards and 
strategic use of extra draw bonuses and shit,

but then at the very end, the game sets 
up a super hard final boss card battle,

and I was all set to demonstrate my acquired 
skills in knowing which numbers are bigger

than others, but then the fucking plot 
takes over and wins the match for you.

Thanks, Promise Mascot Agency. I was almost 
playing a video game for a second there.

Other weak links include that if you want to sell 
merchandise for the extra income stream, you have

to play a tedious claw machine minigame over and 
over again. Yes, I know we&#39;re referencing the way

Yakuza games always have claw machine minigames, 
but crucially, it&#39;s never been mandatory. I hate

claw machines. If I wanted to press a button and 
feel disappointed, I&#39;d buy expired jam. Come to

think of it, there are a lot of weak links 
in this chain. Story&#39;s kinda predictable, I

instantly fingered the twist villain in his first 
fucking scene, and not the good kind of fingering.

And while the game says each of your recruited 
mascots have different needs and strengths,

they really fucking don&#39;t. Just promise every 
single one of them a regular bonus and time

off at the weekends and fling them at whatever 
jobs&#39;ll take them; they all function the same,

waddle about, wiggle the little arms, be very 
bad at transporting stacked crockery. None

of this is a deal breaker because the core 
gameplay, i.e., exploring the sandbox map,

is—if you&#39;ll forgive the technical language—fun, 
and everything else is just an excuse to do it.

The crucial point is that you explore the map 
in a beaten up but mysteriously indestructible

truck you&#39;re not allowed to get out of, so 
you can&#39;t just beeline for your destinations,

you&#39;ve got to navigate the roads, dodgy suspension 
be damned. Which is (a) very amusing when you ramp

off a hill at high speed and Dukes of Hazzard your 
way through someone&#39;s vegetable garden with your

little pink blob friend squealing with excitement 
in the back, and (b) an engaging challenge &#39;cause

the physics are tough to wrestle with even after 
you unlock the truck&#39;s inadequately explained

ability to fly. All weak links aside, the only 
thing you should take away is that I never stopped

looking forward to my sessions with Promise Mascot 
Agency &#39;cause it&#39;s silly and fun, and the gameplay

makes me laugh, and the characters make me smile 
without even having to get their tits out. Also,

the more you play, the more you catch yourself 
accepting the whole premise as normal, leading

to hilarious moments when passers-by glance 
at what you&#39;re doing out of context and go,

&quot;Why is that sinister-looking professional 
criminal having a tense back-alley stand-off

with a seven-foot pink cartoon cat?&quot; Good 
question. Maybe he called him a pussy.
